data.title: Prince Mikasa of Japan
data.meta_description: In 1931 Japan invaded China. Twelve years later Prince Mikasa, the youngest brother of Emperor Hirohito, served for a year with the Imperial Japanese Army in the occupied Chinese city of Nanking (now
data.text:
In 1931 Japan invaded China. Twelve years later Prince Mikasa, the youngest brother of Emperor Hirohito, served for a year with the Imperial Japanese Army in the occupied Chinese city of Nanking (now Nanjing). The junior staff officer, who hid behind the pseudonym Wakasugi, was appalled by the atrocities his fellow Japanese soldiers were committing in what he called a “war of aggression”.

“I was strongly shocked when an officer told me that the best way to train new soldiers is to use a living prisoner of war as the target of bayonet practice,” the prince recalled much later. At the headquarters of the infamous Unit 731, which developed and tested biological and chemical weapons, he saw films of Chinese prisoners being forced to “march
